title: Implement token-based authentication for API
description: Implement token-based authentication system to secure API access without OAuth complexity. Generate API tokens that can be revoked, use Bearer token authentication headers, and store tokens securely in database. This enables external services to authenticate without user credentials. Non-goal: don't build OAuth provider or user management. Acceptance criteria: tokens can be generated/revoked, Bearer token auth works, tokens stored securely, invalid tokens rejected.

title: Create POST /api/drafts endpoint
description: Create POST /api/drafts endpoint to accept draft submissions from external services. This is the core write-only API that makes DashText a universal sink. Implement SvelteKit API route, validate content field, handle optional metadata, and return proper HTTP responses. Non-goal: don't create GET/PUT/DELETE endpoints. Acceptance criteria: POST creates new draft, content field required, metadata optional, proper HTTP status codes.

title: Epic 2.2 — API-First Ingestion UX
description: API-First Ingestion UX - Make API ingestion feel first-class, not bolted on. This includes token management UI, per-token labeling, ingestion logs, and source attribution display. The goal is to make API-created drafts feel native to the application. Non-goals: no connector setup UI, no OAuth integration. This is important because API ingestion should feel seamless and integrated, not like a peripheral feature.

title: Implement rate limiting and abuse protection
description: Implement rate limiting and abuse protection to prevent API misuse while keeping it accessible. Apply per-token rate limits, implement simple sliding window algorithm, return proper HTTP 429 responses, and log abuse attempts. This protects the service without complex infrastructure. Non-goal: don't build sophisticated fraud detection. Acceptance criteria: per-token rate limits enforced, HTTP 429 responses on limit exceeded, basic abuse logging, reasonable limits for legitimate use.

title: Implement source attribution display in UI
description: Implement source attribution display in UI to show API-created drafts' origins. Display source field from API payload, show token labels as source identifiers, add visual indicators for API-created drafts, and include source info in draft metadata. This makes API ingestion feel first-class and integrated. Acceptance criteria: source field displayed in UI, token labels shown as source, API drafts visually distinct, source info preserved in metadata.

title: Epic 2.1 — Capture API (Write-Only)
description: Capture API (Write-Only) - Enable automation without building integrations by implementing a write-only API. This includes token-based authentication, POST /api/drafts endpoint, minimal payload validation, idempotency keys, and rate limiting. The API follows the constraint of being boring, stable, and write-first. Non-goals: no read API, no webhooks out, no user automation UI. This is critical because it enables DashText to become a universal sink without becoming an automation platform.

title: Implement graceful handling of missing metadata
description: Implement graceful handling of missing metadata to make the API more forgiving. Accept requests without optional fields, provide sensible defaults for missing source information, handle malformed metadata without failure, and log unexpected input patterns. This makes the API robust for various integration scenarios. Acceptance criteria: missing metadata handled gracefully, sensible defaults applied, malformed input doesn't break API, useful error messages for debugging.

title: Epic 2.3 — Email / Webhook Friendly Formats (Optional)
description: Email / Webhook Friendly Formats (Optional) - Make API usage ergonomic without extra tooling by accepting plain-text POST bodies and minimal form-encoded input. This enables simple email forwarding and webhook integrations without complex JSON payload construction. The goal is to lower the barrier for basic automation. Non-goal: don't build full email server or webhook processing system.

title: Accept minimal form-encoded input
description: Accept minimal form-encoded input for webhooks and HTML forms. Parse application/x-www-form-urlencoded content, extract content and optional source fields, handle multipart form data gracefully, and provide fallback for missing JSON Content-Type. This enables webhook integration from services that don't support custom JSON. Acceptance criteria: form data parsed correctly, content field extracted, optional source fields handled, webhook compatibility.

title: Phase 3 — Import / Export & Portability (Plain Text Longevity)
description:
Phase 3 establishes import/export capabilities ensuring DashText is not a silo. Users can back up or leave DashText at any time, making plain-text longevity real rather than just marketing.

**Strategic Goal:** DashText is not a silo

**Components:**
- Export functionality (Plain Text First)  
- Import capabilities for external data
- Portability framework for data migration

**Exit Criteria:**
- Users can back up or leave DashText at any time
- Plain-text longevity is real, not marketing

**Non-Goals:**
- No live file sync (one-way import/export only)
- No vault-mode editing (DashText remains the editor)
- No proprietary formats (plain text only)

title: Epic 3.1 — Export (Plain Text First)
description:
Establishes core export functionality ensuring users can get their drafts out of DashText in standard plain-text formats. This is the foundation for data portability and backup capabilities.

**Strategic Context:** Export is the first step toward ensuring DashText is not a silo. Users must be able to reliably export their drafts in standard formats for backup, migration, or external processing.

**Components:**
- Individual draft export to Markdown
- Deterministic frontmatter generation  
- Optional JSON sidecar for metadata
- Filtered export sets (Inbox, Archive)

**Non-Goals:**
- No live file sync (manual export only)
- No vault-mode editing (exports are read-only copies)
- No proprietary formats (Markdown and JSON only)

**Success Criteria:**
- Users can export any single draft as Markdown
- Batch exports work for filtered sets
- Frontmatter is consistent and parseable
- Metadata is preserved in JSON sidecar

title: Implement Markdown export for individual drafts
description:
Core export functionality that converts individual drafts to standard Markdown format with UUID-based filenames. This is the foundation for all other export capabilities.

**Implementation Details:**
- Create export service in src/lib/services/export.ts
- Export function: exportDraftAsMarkdown(draftId: string) -> Promise<string>
- File naming: <uuid>.md (using draft UUID)
- Content conversion: Plain text to Markdown format
- File dialog integration for folder selection

**Strategic Context:** Single draft export is the building block for batch operations and enables users to share individual drafts or move them to other tools.

**Non-Goals:**
- No complex formatting (preserve plain text structure)
- No image/media handling (text only)
- No automatic folder creation (user chooses destination)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Individual draft exports as <uuid>.md file
- Export preserves original content exactly
- User can choose export destination via file dialog
- Export completes without errors for valid drafts
- Keyboard shortcut available (Ctrl/Cmd+E)

title: Add deterministic frontmatter generation
description:
Generates consistent, parseable YAML frontmatter for exported Markdown files using draft metadata. Enables downstream tools to understand draft properties.

**Implementation Details:**
- Extend export service with frontmatter generation
- Frontmatter fields: id, created_at, updated_at, source, source_url (if available)
- Deterministic format: Same fields always appear in same order
- Optional frontmatter: User can choose to include or exclude
- Integration with existing draft metadata schema

**Strategic Context:** Frontmatter makes exported files intelligible to other static site generators, note-taking apps, and processing tools.

**Non-Goals:**
- No custom frontmatter templates (fixed schema only)
- No processing of existing frontmatter in imports
- No dynamic field addition (static schema only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Frontmatter appears at top of exported Markdown files
- Fields are consistently ordered and formatted
- YAML syntax is valid and parseable
- Optional frontmatter can be toggled in export UI
- All metadata fields are properly escaped

title: Create optional JSON sidecar for metadata
description:
Creates JSON sidecar files containing complete draft metadata for advanced use cases and data preservation. Enables full reconstruction of draft state.

**Implementation Details:**
- Sidecar file naming: <uuid>.json (matching Markdown file)
- Complete metadata export: All draft fields, flags, and relationships
- JSON schema validation for consistency
- Optional sidecar generation (user-controlled)
- Atomic export: Markdown and JSON created together

**Strategic Context:** JSON sidecar preserves all metadata that cannot fit in YAML frontmatter, ensuring complete data portability and potential for full import restoration.

**Non-Goals:**
- No content duplication (metadata only, not draft text)
- No complex JSON structure (flat schema preferred)
- No automatic sidecar processing (manual user choice)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- JSON sidecar contains all draft metadata
- Schema is consistent and documented
- Sidecar files are created alongside Markdown exports
- Optional generation can be toggled in UI
- JSON is valid and parseable by standard tools

title: Implement filtered export sets (Inbox, Archive)
description:
Enables batch export of filtered draft sets (Inbox, Archive) rather than requiring individual file selection. Supports user workflows for backing up specific draft collections.

**Implementation Details:**
- Extend export service with batch export capabilities
- Filter support: Inbox, Archive, All drafts
- Batch export function: exportFilteredDrafts(filter: string, destination: string)
- Progress tracking for large export operations
- Error handling for individual file failures

**Strategic Context:** Filtered export makes backing up specific draft collections practical and enables users to export only the drafts they care about.

**Non-Goals:**
- No complex filtering (basic Inbox/Archive only)
- No custom filter queries (predefined sets only)
- No scheduled exports (manual only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Users can select Inbox, Archive, or All for export
- Batch export creates multiple files in chosen destination
- Export progress is shown for large operations
- Individual file failures don't stop entire batch
- All drafts in selected set are exported successfully

title: Add batch export UI and keyboard shortcuts
description:
Provides user interface and keyboard shortcuts for initiating export operations. Makes export functionality discoverable and accessible through standard interaction patterns.

**Implementation Details:**
- Export menu item in main application menu
- Export dialog UI with options (frontmatter, sidecar, filters)
- Keyboard shortcuts: Ctrl/Cmd+E (single draft), Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+E (batch)
- Context menu option for individual draft export
- Export status feedback and completion notifications

**Strategic Context:** UI and keyboard integration makes export functionality discoverable and aligns with user expectations for desktop applications.

**Non-Goals:**
- No complex export wizard (simple dialog only)
- No automated export scheduling (manual triggers only)
- No export templates (fixed options only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Export option appears in main application menu
- Keyboard shortcuts work consistently across platforms
- Export dialog presents all relevant options clearly
- Context menu provides export for selected drafts
- Users receive feedback on export completion

title: Epic 3.2 — Import
description:
Enables users to import external Markdown files and folders into DashText, completing the round-trip data portability story. Makes DashText a viable destination for existing text collections.

**Strategic Context:** Import is the counterpart to export, ensuring users can migrate existing text collections into DashText. This makes DashText accessible to users with existing plain-text workflows.

**Components:**
- Markdown folder import functionality
- Conflict detection and handling
- Original timestamp preservation
- Duplicate resolution strategies

**Non-Goals:**
- No live file sync (one-way import only)
- No automatic file watching
- No complex import rules (simple folder import)

**Success Criteria:**
- Users can import entire Markdown folders
- Conflicts are detected and presented clearly
- Original file timestamps are preserved when possible
- Import process is reversible and safe

title: Implement Markdown folder import functionality
description:
Core import functionality that processes Markdown files from a selected folder and creates drafts in DashText. Enables users to migrate existing text collections into DashText.

**Implementation Details:**
- Create import service in src/lib/services/import.ts
- Import function: importMarkdownFolder(folderPath: string) -> Promise<ImportResult>
- File discovery: Recursive scan for .md files
- Content extraction: Strip frontmatter if present, extract body content
- Draft creation: Generate new UUIDs for imported drafts

**Strategic Context:** Folder import makes DashText accessible to users with existing plain-text workflows and enables migration from other tools.

**Non-Goals:**
- No automatic file watching (one-time import only)
- No complex file filtering (all .md files imported)
- No live folder sync (manual import only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Users can select a folder for import via file dialog
- All .md files in folder and subfolders are imported
- Imported content appears as new drafts in DashText
- Import process handles folders with dozens of files
- Users receive feedback on import completion and results

title: Add conflict detection and handling for imports
description:
Detects and handles conflicts when imported files might duplicate existing drafts. Provides clear user choice for how to handle potential duplicates.

**Implementation Details:**
- Conflict detection based on content similarity and file metadata
- Conflict resolution UI with options: Skip, Replace, Keep Both, Rename
- Import service extension with conflict handling logic
- Batch conflict resolution for multiple files
- Import log showing conflicts and resolutions

**Strategic Context:** Conflict handling prevents data loss and gives users control over how imports interact with existing drafts.

**Non-Goals:**
- No automatic conflict resolution (user choice required)
- No complex diff visualization (simple indication only)
- No rollback functionality (forward-only import)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Import process detects potential duplicate content
- Users see clear options for handling each conflict
- Batch resolution allows handling multiple conflicts at once
- Import continues after conflict resolution choices
- Import summary shows conflicts and their resolutions

title: Create timestamp preservation for imported files
description:
Preserves original file creation and modification timestamps when importing Markdown files. Maintains chronological context of imported content.

**Implementation Details:**
- Timestamp extraction from file system metadata
- Import service extension for timestamp preservation
- Fallback strategy: Use file modification date if creation date unavailable
- Frontmatter handling: Respect existing created_at/updated_at in YAML frontmatter
- Database schema support for import timestamps

**Strategic Context:** Timestamp preservation maintains the chronological context of imported content and respects the original creation timeline.

**Non-Goals:**
- No timezone conversion (preserve original timezone)
- No timestamp manipulation (preserve as-is)
- No automatic timestamp generation (preserve original only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Imported drafts use original file creation dates
- File modification timestamps are preserved when available
- Existing frontmatter timestamps take precedence over file dates
- Import doesn't create drafts with current date/time
- Timestamps are displayed correctly in Dashtext UI

title: Implement duplicate resolution strategies
description:
Provides strategies for handling duplicate content during import, allowing users to control how similar drafts are processed. Enables safe import without data loss.

**Implementation Details:**
- Duplicate detection algorithm: Content similarity and metadata comparison
- Resolution strategies: Keep Original, Keep New, Keep Both, Merge
- Import service extension with duplicate resolution logic
- User choice persistence for consistent handling across imports
- Import preview showing potential duplicates before import

**Strategic Context:** Duplicate resolution gives users control over import behavior and prevents accidental data overwrite while enabling comprehensive migration.

**Non-Goals:**
- No automatic merging (user-controlled only)
- No complex diff display (simple indication only)
- No undo functionality (forward-only import)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Import process identifies potential duplicates before processing
- Users can choose default strategy for handling duplicates
- Individual duplicate decisions override default strategy
- Import preview shows all potential duplicates
- Users can proceed with import after reviewing duplicates

title: Epic 3.3 — Portability Framework
description:
Provides the underlying framework and utilities that make import/export operations reliable, safe, and user-friendly. Ensures data integrity throughout portability operations.

**Strategic Context:** The portability framework is the foundation that makes import/export operations trustworthy. It handles validation, error recovery, and data integrity protections.

**Components:**
- Data validation and integrity checking
- Backup/restore workflow utilities
- Cross-platform compatibility layer
- Migration and upgrade tools

**Non-Goals:**
- No automatic sync (manual operations only)
- No cloud integration (local framework only)
- No third-party service integrations

**Success Criteria:**
- Import/export operations are atomic and safe
- Data corruption is detected and prevented
- Backup workflows are reliable and tested
- Cross-platform portability is consistent

title: Implement data validation and integrity checking
description:
Validates data integrity during import/export operations to prevent corruption and ensure reliable portability operations. Detects and prevents common data issues.

**Implementation Details:**
- Validation service in src/lib/services/validation.ts
- Content validation: UTF-8 encoding, proper Markdown syntax
- Metadata validation: Required fields, proper data types
- File system validation: Permissions, disk space, path validity
- Error reporting with clear user feedback

**Strategic Context:** Data validation ensures import/export operations are safe and reliable, preventing data loss and maintaining user trust.

**Non-Goals:**
- No complex content parsing (basic validation only)
- No automatic data repair (prevention and reporting only)
- No historical validation (current state only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Invalid files are detected before processing
- Validation errors are clearly explained to users
- Operations are aborted when critical issues are found
- Non-critical issues are reported with warnings
- Validation completes quickly for typical file sizes

title: Create backup/restore workflow utilities
description:
Provides backup and restore utilities to protect user data during major operations and enable safe recovery. Creates safety nets for import/export workflows.

**Implementation Details:**
- Backup service in src/lib/services/backup.ts
- Automatic backup before major import operations
- Manual backup triggers for user-initiated safety
- Restore functionality for recovering from failed operations
- Backup format: SQLite dump with metadata

**Strategic Context:** Backup/restore utilities give users confidence to perform import/export operations knowing they can recover if something goes wrong.

**Non-Goals:**
- No automatic scheduled backups (manual triggers only)
- No cloud backup integration (local backups only)
- No incremental backups (full backups only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Automatic backup created before risky import operations
- Users can trigger manual backups at any time
- Restore functionality can recover from failed imports
- Backup files are clearly named and dated
- Users receive feedback on backup completion and status

title: Add cross-platform compatibility layer
description:
Ensures import/export functionality works consistently across all supported platforms (Windows, macOS, Linux). Handles platform-specific file system and UI differences.

**Implementation Details:**
- Platform abstraction layer in src/lib/platform/
- File dialog integration for each platform's native dialogs
- Path handling for different operating system path formats
- Permission handling for file system access
- Platform-specific keyboard shortcuts and UI patterns

**Strategic Context:** Cross-platform compatibility ensures all users have reliable import/export functionality regardless of their operating system.

**Non-Goals:**
- No platform-specific features (consistent experience)
- No advanced platform integrations (basic compatibility only)
- No platform-specific optimizations (shared codebase)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Import/export works on Windows, macOS, and Linux
- File dialogs use native platform appearance
- Keyboard shortcuts follow platform conventions
- File permissions are handled correctly on each platform
- Error messages are appropriate for each platform

title: Implement migration and upgrade tools
description:
Provides tools for migrating data between different versions of DashText and upgrading from older data formats. Ensures forward compatibility during application updates.

**Implementation Details:**
- Migration service in src/lib/services/migration.ts
- Version detection and format validation
- Data schema migration utilities
- Upgrade path validation and testing
- Rollback capability for failed migrations

**Strategic Context:** Migration tools ensure users can upgrade DashText without losing data and maintain compatibility with existing import/export workflows.

**Non-Goals:**
- No automatic migrations (user-controlled only)
- No cross-application migrations (DashText only)
- No downgrading support (forward migration only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Migration service detects data version compatibility
- Users can initiate data format upgrades manually
- Migration process preserves all existing data
- Failed migrations can be rolled back safely
- Users receive clear feedback on migration status

title: Create export/import operation logging
description:
Creates comprehensive logging for all import/export operations to enable troubleshooting, audit trails, and operational insights. Provides visibility into portability operations.

**Implementation Details:**
- Logging service in src/lib/services/logging.ts
- Operation logging: Start time, duration, file counts, success/failure
- Error logging: Detailed error information with context
- Log file management: Rotation, cleanup, size limits
- User-facing operation history and status

**Strategic Context:** Operation logging enables troubleshooting of import/export issues and provides audit trails for data movements.

**Non-Goals:**
- No real-time monitoring (batch logging only)
- No external log integration (local logging only)
- No complex log analysis (basic viewing only)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- All import/export operations are logged automatically
- Log entries include timestamps, file counts, and success status
- Error logs contain sufficient detail for troubleshooting
- Users can view recent operation history
- Log files don't grow unbounded (rotation implemented)

title: Add optional idempotency key support
description: Add optional idempotency key support to prevent duplicate draft creation on retries. External services can include idempotency key in request, store key with draft for configured time, return existing draft if key reused. This makes the API safe for automation without complex state management. Non-goal: don't build full deduplication system. Acceptance criteria: idempotency key optional, duplicate requests return existing draft, keys expire after time limit, hash collision handling.

title: Implement per-token labeling system
description: Implement per-token labeling system to identify different API clients. Allow users to add custom labels like 'n8n', 'email', 'scripts', store labels with tokens, display labels in ingestion logs, and use labels in source attribution. This makes API management intuitive for multiple use cases. Non-goal: don't build complex categorization system. Acceptance criteria: custom labels configurable, labels persist with tokens, labels shown in logs, clear labeling interface.

title: Implement minimal payload validation
description: Implement minimal payload validation for the POST /api/drafts endpoint. Validate required content field, accept optional metadata fields (source, source_url, created_at), and handle malformed requests gracefully. This ensures API reliability while keeping it simple. Follow the payload example from roadmap as guiding constraint. Acceptance criteria: content field validated, optional metadata accepted, clear error messages for bad requests, malformed payloads rejected.

title: Remove inline backgroundColor from theme bootstrap
Fix critical CSS to use @media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) fallback
Phase 1 — Drafts Core (Local Trust & Capture)
description: Establish stable local data model, inbox semantics, and capture parity

title: Epic 1.1 — Core Data Model Hardening
description: Core Data Model Hardening - Establish the foundational data model that Phase 2+ features depend on. This epic adds stable UUIDs (replacing auto-incrementing IDs), timestamp fields for sync lifecycle tracking, soft delete capability, archive state, pinning, and safe migration scripts. Non-goals: no UI changes, no breaking changes to existing drafts. This is critical because future sync features (Phase 5) depend on identifiers that don't change when drafts are merged between devices.

title: Implement soft delete functionality
description: Add soft delete functionality with deleted_at column to preserve drafts while hiding them from normal views. This follows Drafts app behavior where deleted drafts aren't immediately removed permanently. Update schema, queries, and UI to respect soft delete. Acceptance criteria: soft delete marks deleted_at timestamp, deleted drafts don't appear in lists, optional restore functionality.

title: Add pinned flag for drafts
description: Add optional pinned flag for important drafts that should remain visible, following Drafts app behavior where pinned drafts stay at the top of views. This is different from archived - pinned drafts stay visible and prioritized. Update schema and migrations. Acceptance criteria: pinned flag defaults to false, pinned drafts appear at top of lists, multiple pins are allowed.

title: Create safe migration system for schema changes
description: Implement safe migration system to handle schema changes without breaking existing drafts, using Drizzle migrations. This is crucial because future phases depend on reliable data migrations. Create migration scripts that can be safely rolled back and handle edge cases. Acceptance criteria: migrations run automatically on app start, existing data is preserved, rollback works without data loss.

title: Create safe migration system for schema changes
Implement stable UUID generation for drafts
Implement stable UUID generation for drafts
description: Replace the current auto-incrementing ID system with stable UUIDs in the Draft model. This is critical because future sync features (Phase 5) depend on identifiers that don't change when drafts are merged between devices. Update the Draft schema in src/lib/db/schema.ts and create a migration script to preserve existing drafts. Non-goal: don't update any UI components yet - this is purely backend data model work. Acceptance criteria: all drafts have stable UUIDs, migration preserves existing data.

title: Add created_at and updated_at timestamps
description: Add created_at and updated_at timestamp fields to the Draft model to track draft lifecycle and support future sync operations. These timestamps are essential for Phase 5 sync to determine which draft version is newer during conflicts. Update the Draft schema and migration scripts. Acceptance criteria: timestamps are automatically set on creation/update, existing drafts get reasonable default values.

title: Add archived boolean field
description: Add archived boolean field to the Draft model to support inbox semantics while keeping drafts accessible. This enables the Archive action without deletion, following Drafts app behavior where archived drafts are preserved but hidden from active views. Update schema and migrations. Acceptance criteria: archived field defaults to false, archived drafts are queryable but hidden from default views.

title: Epic 1.2 — Inbox Semantics
description: Inbox Semantics - Implement lightweight processing workflow without becoming a full GTD system. This adds default Inbox view, keyboard-first Archive action, filtered views, and hides archived content. Non-goals: no priorities, no due dates, no task management. Purpose: allow drafts to be processed without data loss, following Drafts app behavior where archived drafts are kept but hidden from active processing.

title: Set Inbox as default view on app start
description: Set Inbox as the default view on app start to enable frictionless capture, following Drafts app behavior where new drafts go to Inbox. This ensures DashText becomes the default intake everywhere. Update routing and draft store initialization. Acceptance criteria: app opens to Inbox view, new drafts default to Inbox, capture remains frictionless.

title: Implement Archive action for drafts
description: Implement keyboard-first Archive action to move drafts out of Inbox without deletion, following Drafts app behavior. This enables lightweight processing without becoming a full GTD system. Add keyboard shortcut (Cmd+Shift+A) and UI action. Acceptance criteria: Archive action moves draft to archived state, keyboard shortcut works, archived drafts stay accessible.

title: Create Inbox-only filtered view
description: Create Inbox-only filtered view to focus on unprocessed drafts, following Drafts app behavior where working drafts are separated from processed content. This enables lightweight processing workflow. Add filtered view and navigation. Acceptance criteria: filtered view shows only unarchived drafts, navigation includes Inbox filter, processed drafts are hidden.

title: Hide archived drafts from main views
description: Hide archived drafts from main views to reduce clutter, following Drafts app behavior where processed content moves to background. This enables users to focus on active processing without losing data. Update queries and UI components. Acceptance criteria: archived drafts don't appear in main lists, archived content remains accessible in drafts store, processed drafts background cleanly.

title: Make pin feature optional/inbox-only
description: Make pin feature optional/inbox-only to maintain focus on active processing, following Drafts app behavior where pinning is primarily for active drafts. This prevents pinning from becoming a task management system. Update UI and behavior. Acceptance criteria: pinning only works on Inbox drafts, pinned drafts stay visible without distraction, pin behavior doesn't create task management.

title: Epic 1.3 — Capture Parity (Manual)
description: Capture Parity - Make DashText the default intake everywhere by matching Drafts app behavior. This includes desktop quick-capture, web capture route, mobile optimization, consistent save semantics, and keyboard shortcuts. Goal: never hesitate about where to capture something. Non-goals: no sync yet, no automation. This is critical because DashText must become the best possible place for things to land - only later does it become a place things leave from.

title: Implement desktop quick-capture workflow
description: Implement desktop quick-capture workflow to make DashText the default intake everywhere, following Drafts app behavior. This includes global hotkey support, quick window capture, and seamless draft creation. Update Tauri window management and keyboard shortcuts. Acceptance criteria: global hotkey creates new draft window, quick capture saves automatically, capture feels frictionless and default.

title: Create web /capture route for quick drafts
description: Create web /capture route with minimal UI to make DashText the default intake everywhere, following Drafts app behavior. This enables browser-based capture without full app. Add SvelteKit route and minimal capture interface. Acceptance criteria: /capture route loads quickly, minimal UI for fast drafting, captured drafts save to Inbox automatically.

title: Make capture interface mobile-friendly
description: Make capture interface mobile-friendly to ensure cross-platform parity, following Drafts app behavior where capture works equally well on mobile. This includes responsive design, touch-friendly controls, and mobile keyboard optimization. Acceptance criteria: capture interface works on mobile browsers, touch controls are intuitive, mobile keyboard doesn't cover content.

title: Ensure consistent save/close behavior across platforms
description: Implement consistent save/close behavior across platforms following Drafts app behavior where save automatically happens and close doesn't lose data. This ensures users can trust DashText as their default intake. Update window management and auto-save logic. Acceptance criteria: drafts save automatically, close doesn't lose work, behavior consistent across desktop/web.

title: Add keyboard shortcuts for capture
description: Add keyboard shortcuts for capture parity following Drafts app behavior where capture is keyboard-first. This is essential for DashText to become the default intake everywhere. Add keyboard shortcuts and vim integration. Acceptance criteria: Cmd+N creates new draft, common shortcuts work, vim mode respects capture behavior.

title: Add basic ingestion logs and last-seen indicator
description: Add basic ingestion logs and last-seen indicator to track API usage. Show recent API submissions, display timestamp of last successful request per token, log basic request metadata, and provide simple log viewing interface. This helps users understand API activity without complex monitoring. Non-goal: don't build comprehensive analytics system. Acceptance criteria: recent submissions visible, last-seen timestamps accurate, basic request metadata logged, simple log interface.

title: Create minimal API documentation with examples
description: Create minimal API documentation with working examples to enable external integration. Document POST /api/drafts endpoint, payload format, authentication method, error responses, and provide curl/n8n/script examples. Keep it minimal but sufficient for external developers. Non-goal: don't build comprehensive API reference site. Acceptance criteria: endpoint documented, payload format shown, auth method explained, working examples provided, error responses documented.

title: Accept plain-text POST bodies for simple content
description: Accept plain-text POST bodies for simple content creation without JSON wrapper. Enable direct text submission to /api/drafts endpoint, use request body as draft content, parse content-length header properly, and handle encoding gracefully. This makes the API accessible from simple tools like curl without JSON construction. Acceptance criteria: plain-text submissions work, content used as draft body, proper encoding handling, simple tool integration.

title: Add generate/revoke API tokens functionality
description: Add generate/revoke API tokens functionality in settings UI. Create secure token generation interface, display tokens with copy-to-clipboard, provide revoke confirmation, and show token usage summary. This enables users to manage API access without external tools. Non-goal: don't build full user management system. Acceptance criteria: tokens can be generated in UI, tokens revocable with confirmation, copy-to-clipboard works, token list shows usage.

title: Phase 2 — Capture API (Universal Sink)
description: Capture API - Make DashText a universal sink where anything can send text. This phase enables automation without building integrations, focusing on write-only API, token-based authentication, and API-first ingestion UX. Goal: DashText becomes a place anything can send text, enabling automation without becoming a platform. Non-goals: no read API, no webhooks out, no user automation UI. This is the most important structural phase because capture comes before processing and APIs are boring, stable, and write-first.
